text: does anyone have a leftover Lit sauce I could purchase?
i saved a few boxes for us, i think it was in the storage room in the old space. not sure where it is now though.

OK gardening food folks, I have a dilemma that maybe you can help with. I finally got a plot in my local-ish community garden, which is great. I'm torn, however.  My home garden is all planned out for the summer, so we have (hopefully) most of our needs being met. I'm unsure what to do with this windfall of land. 

Do I make things easy on myself by planting a bunch of the same food (ie peppers or melons) so that when I visit upkeep is relatively easy, and I can plan to harvest and replant in pretty narrow timeframes, or do I keep the same sort of variety I have at home and just lump the fact that the upkeep will be a little more intense?
yeah, that seems easiest--dump a bunch of the same stuff in, and then it'll all be ready more or less at the same time
you could do perennials, like strawberries, artichokes, fennel
or like you said things that grow on a longer timeline
yeah I have a good winter lineup I think, leeks / carrots / cabbage
man i have not planned out my garden AT ALL

attachments.title: Melons - Organic - Minnesota Midget Melon Conventional & Organic
attachments.text: 65-70 days. This exquisite heirloom produces a bounty of early, and true to its name, mini cantaloupes. Fruit measure 4-6 inches across and have deep orange flesh that is succulent, sweet, and delicious down to the rind. The ultimate melon for short-season areas, and the compact plants are ideal for small space or container gardens. HR: F.
attachments.fallback: Melons - Organic - Minnesota Midget Melon Conventional & Organic

gonna try to make these ones work
esp since I have no idea of this plot's soil condition, I can basically make big mulchy-fertilized hills and plant them there
nice! i’ve never grown melons. i may give up on summer and winter squash this year too because i dont have enough calcium in my soil and i should have acted on that last year
